summary: This document is a compilation of news clips from the SDNY dated April 9, 2019. It primarily features a legal commentary article by Joel Cohen from the New York Law Journal discussing prosecutorial discretion, using the Jeffrey Epstein case as a central example of its potential misuse. The article critiques the lenient 2008 prosecution deal Epstein received in Florida.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the legal commentary, described as having a 'sordid history of engaging in (criminal) physical relations with and serial rape of underage girls,' whose case exemplifies questionable prosecutorial discretion.

persons.name: Joel Cohen
persons.context: Author of the featured legal commentary article. A former prosecutor and senior counsel at Stroock & Stroock & Lavan who analyzes the concept of prosecutorial discretion.

persons.name: Dale J. Degenshein
persons.context: Special counsel at Stroock who assisted Joel Cohen in the preparation of the legal commentary article.

persons.name: Bennett Gershman
persons.context: Author of 'Prosecutorial Misconduct,' a key legal text cited extensively in the article to define and discuss the scope of prosecutorial discretion.

persons.name: Robert H. Jackson
persons.context: Former U.S. Attorney General and Supreme Court Justice whose famous speech on the 'dangerous power of the prosecutor' is quoted in the article.

connections.description: Cohen's legal commentary uses the Epstein case as the primary example to analyze failures in prosecutorial discretion.
Degenshein assisted Cohen in the preparation of the legal commentary article.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Prosecution and Plea Deal
events.description: Epstein faced state prosecution in West Palm Beach, Florida, and a related federal investigation in Miami. The federal case was folded into the local prosecution, resulting in a non-prosecution agreement federally and a guilty plea in state court. Epstein served 13 months in a private jail wing with work release.

events.title: Federal Judge Revisits Epstein Deal
events.description: A federal district judge, revisiting the Epstein case, found that the U.S. attorney violated the federal Crime Victims Reporting Act by not notifying victims of the non-prosecution agreement settlement.

events.title: Inmates of Attica Correctional Facility v. Rockefeller
events.description: A landmark Second Circuit case cited in the article that established courts 'are not to interfere' with the discretionary powers of the U.S. Attorney, reinforcing prosecutorial independence.

keyFacts: The article identifies the Jeffrey Epstein case as a prime example of questionable prosecutorial discretion, where a 'seemingly light' prosecution deal was reached despite serious allegations.
It notes that the U.S. attorney in the Epstein case violated the Crime Victims Reporting Act by failing to notify victims of the non-prosecution agreement, as found by a federal judge in 2019.
The legal analysis centers on the enormous independence of prosecutors in charging decisions, citing legal precedent that courts generally will not interfere with this discretion.

The commentary raises the ethical question of whether prosecutors can or should exercise discretion to decline prosecution for high-profile figures even when evidence of guilt exists, referencing the Mueller investigation as a parallel.
